title: How to Graph Sine and Cosine Functions

steps.headline: Draw a coordinate plane.
steps.description: For a sine or cosine graph, simply go from 0 to 2π on the x-axis, and -1 to 1 on the y-axis, intersecting at the origin (0, 0). Both y=sin⁡(x){\displaystyle y=\sin(x)} and y=cos⁡(x){\displaystyle y=\cos(x)} repeat the same shape from negative infinity to positive infinity on the x-axis (you'll generally only graph a portion of it). Use the basic equations as given: y=sin⁡(x){\displaystyle y=\sin(x)} and y=cos(x){\displaystyle y=cos(x)}

steps.headline: Graph the basic form of y=sin⁡(x){\displaystyle y=\sin(x)}.
steps.description: Plot and connect the points (0, 0), (π/2, 1), (π, 0), and (3π/2, -1) with a continuous curve. Both y=sin⁡(x){\displaystyle y=\sin(x)} and y=cos⁡(x){\displaystyle y=\cos(x)} never go past -1 or 1 on the y-axis. Since you are only hand-drawing your graphs, there is no precise scale, but it must be accurate at certain points.

steps.headline: Graph the basic form of y=cos(x){\displaystyle y=cos(x)}.
steps.description: Plot and connect the points (0, 1), (π/2, 0), (π, -1), and (3π/2, 0) with a continuous curve. It may be helpful to use two separate colors to distinguish between sine and cosine.

steps.headline: Use the standard equation to define your variables.
Calculate the period.

steps.headline: Calculate the amplitude.
Calculate the phase shift.
Calculate the vertical shift.
Graph the final function.
steps.description: After each transformation has been applied, your graph is finished!

Graphing calculator or software to check your work (optional)
sentences: Graphing the Basic Equations Draw a coordinate plane.
For a sine or cosine graph, simply go from 0 to 2π on the x-axis, and -1 to 1 on the y-axis, intersecting at the origin (0, 0).

Both y=sin⁡(x){\displaystyle y=\sin(x)} and y=cos⁡(x){\displaystyle y=\cos(x)} repeat the same shape from negative infinity to positive infinity on the x-axis (you'll generally only graph a portion of it).
Use the basic equations as given: y=sin⁡(x){\displaystyle y=\sin(x)} and y=cos(x){\displaystyle y=cos(x)} Graph the basic form of y=sin⁡(x){\displaystyle y=\sin(x)}.
Plot and connect the points (0, 0), (π/2, 1), (π, 0), and (3π/2, -1) with a continuous curve.
Both y=sin⁡(x){\displaystyle y=\sin(x)} and y=cos⁡(x){\displaystyle y=\cos(x)} never go past -1 or 1 on the y-axis.
Since you are only hand-drawing your graphs, there is no precise scale, but it must be accurate at certain points.
Graph the basic form of y=cos(x){\displaystyle y=cos(x)}.
Plot and connect the points (0, 1), (π/2, 0), (π, -1), and (3π/2, 0) with a continuous curve.
It may be helpful to use two separate colors to distinguish between sine and cosine.
Graphing Different Sine Equations Use the standard equation to define your variables.
Calculate the period.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/3\/3e\/Sinx_period_change.gif","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/3\/3e\/Sinx_period_change.gif\/300px-Sinx_period_change.gif","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":"300","bigHeight":"300","licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Divide your period on the x-axis into four sections that are equal distances apart, just like in the basic equations.
The y-values will still alternate from 0, 1, 0, and -1 just like in the basic equation.
Period=2πB{\displaystyle {\text{Period}}={\frac {2\pi }{B}}} Calculate the amplitude.
If A is negative, the graph will flip over the x-axis.
This is called a reflection.
Calculate the phase shift.
For each x-value in the period, move the x-value to the left by C/B if C/B is negative, or move each x-value to the right by C/B if C/B is positive.
Calculate the vertical shift.
Graph the final function.
After each transformation has been applied, your graph is finished!
Graphing Different Cosine Equations Use the standard equation to define your variables.
Calculate the period.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/c\/c4\/Cosx_period_change.gif","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/c\/c4\/Cosx_period_change.gif\/300px-Cosx_period_change.gif","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":"300","bigHeight":"300","licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Divide your period on the x-axis into four sections that are equal distances apart, just like in the basic equations.
The y-values will still alternate from 1, 0, -1, and 0 just like in the basic equation.
Period=2πB{\displaystyle {\text{Period}}={\frac {2\pi }{B}}} Calculate the amplitude.
If A is negative, the graph will flip over the x-axis.
This is called a reflection.
Calculate the phase shift.
For each x-value in the period, move the x-value to the left by C/B if C/B is negative, or move each x-value to the right by C/B if C/B is positive.
Calculate the vertical shift.
For each y-value, move the y-value up by D if D is positive, or move the y-value down if D is negative.
Graph the final function.
After each transformation has been applied, your graph is finished!
